content.text: Describe the motion of the car between time \(= 0\) and time \(= 2.0 \text{s}\)
State the value of the acceleration of the car between time \(= 4.0 \text{s}\) and time \(= 8.0 \text{s}\)
Calculate the distance travelled by the car between time \(= 8.0 \text{s}\) and time \(= 14.0 \text{s}\)
distance travelled = .........\(m\)
Fig. 1.1 shows the speedâ€“time graph for a car travelling along a flat straight road
Describe how the student can find the volume of the piece of metal by using equipment from Fig. 2.1
The volume of a different piece of metal is \(30 \text{cm}^3\). The mass of this piece of metal is \(192 \text{g}\)
Calculate the density of the metal. Include the unit
density of the metal =
unit
A student wants to find the volume of a piece of metal. The student can use any of the items of equipment shown in Fig. 2.1
State and explain which shape is the more stable
the more stable shape is
explanation
The mass of the cylinder is \(0.25 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the weight of the cylinder
weight = .........N
Calculate the moment of the 3.0 N force about the pivot in Fig. 3.2
moment = .........Ncm
Determine the moment of the weight of the cone about the pivot
Use ideas about the principle of moments
A horizontal force of 3.0 N tilts the cone. The cone balances on one edge, as shown in Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.1 shows two solid shapes, a cylinder and a cone, which are made from the same material
State two ways in which useful energy is transferred from the television
Determine the value of the wasted energy output from the television
wasted energy = .........J
Describe how a hydroelectric power station generates electrical power
Apart from cost, state one advantage and one disadvantage of generating electrical power using a hydroelectric power station compared to a coal-fired power station
advantage
disadvantage
Fig. 4.2 represents a hydroelectric power station
Fig. 4.1 shows a flow diagram for the energy transferred in a television
Describe the arrangement, separation and motion of the particles in the metal block
The temperature of the metal block decreases
Describe any changes in the motion and separation of the particles in the metal block
A scientist cools the metal block until its temperature is close to absolute zero
Describe the motion of the particles in the metal block
The weight of the metal block is \(26 \text{N}\). The area of the metal block in contact with the table is \(42 \text{cm}^2\)
Calculate the pressure on the table due to the metal block
Fig. 5.1 shows a metal block at room temperature on a table
She studies waves on the surface of water in a ripple tank. The frequency of the waves is \(4.0 \text{Hz}\). The wavelength of the waves is \(5.0 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the speed of the waves
The student puts a block into the ripple tank, as shown in Fig. 6.1. The block sinks
The waves travel towards the block and then over the block
State and explain what happens to the waves as they travel over the edge of the block
State the name of one region in Fig. 6.2 that has longer wavelengths than visible light
Describe one use of ultraviolet radiation
Compare the speed of radio waves with the speed of gamma rays as they both travel through a vacuum
The chart in Fig. 6.2 shows the main regions of the electromagnetic spectrum
A student studies different types of wave
The potential difference (p.d.) across lamp L is \(4.8 \text{V}\) and the current in lamp L is \(0.40 \text{A}\)
Calculate the resistance of lamp L
resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
State and explain how closing switch S affects the brightness of lamp L
A battery, a lamp L, a fixed resistor R and a switch S are connected as shown in Fig. 7.1
The battery in a laptop computer is connected to a battery charger for 20 minutes
The potential difference (p.d.) across the battery is \(14\mathrm{V}.\) The current in the battery is \(1.8\mathrm{A}.\)
Calculate the energy transferred to the battery in 20 minutes
energy transferred = .........J
State the name of the material used for the core of the transformer
The transformer has 4800 turns on the primary (input) coil
Calculate the number of turns on the secondary (output) coil
Use information from Fig. 8.1
number of turns = .........
The battery charger includes a transformer. Fig. 8.1 shows the transformer
Fig. 9.1 shows an electricity cable that has a fault
The cable is used for supplying electricity at a high voltage
State the fault and describe the hazard shown in Fig. 9.1
fault
hazard
State the name of wire X in Fig. 9.2
An electrical appliance is connected in the mains circuit. One of the wires in the cable is connected to the switch for the appliance
State and explain which wire is connected to the switch
Fig. 9.2 shows a piece of cable used in a mains circuit
Compare the number of protons in one nucleus of U-235 with the number of protons in one nucleus of U-238
Compare the number of neutrons in one nucleus of U-235 with the number of neutrons in one nucleus of U-238
U-235 and U-238 are isotopes of uranium
Fig. 10.1 shows the nuclide notation for U-235 and for U-238
A sample contains another isotope of uranium. The half-life of this isotope is 24 minutes
Calculate the time taken for the mass of this isotope in the sample to decay from \(16.0 \text{mg}\) to \(4.0 \text{mg}\)
time taken = .........minutes
Venus is a similar size to the Earth
State why the gravitational field strength at the surface of the Earth is greater than the gravitational field strength at the surface of Venus
Calculate the time, in Earth days, for one day on Venus
time = .........Earth days
Calculate the time taken for light to travel from the Sun to Venus. The speed of light is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
time taken = .........\(s\)
The star nearest to the Sun is about 4.25 light-years from the Sun
Explain what is meant by one light-year
Table 11.1 shows some information about two of the planets in the Solar System
